headline: Canadian Yellow Split Pea Soup with Ham
description: Canadian-style yellow split pea soup is a great way to use up a ham bone, or smoked pork hocks. This hearty comforting soup is loaded with flavor.
name: Canadian Yellow Split Pea Soup with Ham
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch ground black pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place ham bone, split peas, celery, carrots, onion, salt, thyme, bay leaf, and pepper into a large pot; pour in water. Bring mixture to a boil and skim off any foam with a spoon.
Reduce the heat and place a lid on the pot, slightly ajar to allow some evaporation. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until peas are tender and soup is thick, about 3 hours.
Remove ham bone from soup; remove meat from ham bone, chop, and return to the pot.

review.reviewBody: Great recipe. Didn’t have thyme, used the same amount of marjoram. Excellent. This will be my go to for pea soup. Always use yellow split peas. I didn’t use any salt.

This soup was great and so quick and easy to make. However like a previous reviewer stated, I would use less salt, one tbsp would have been plenty for me. I also had 3 cups of leftover chicken stock so I used that half and half with the water.
WAY TOO SALTY, Should be 1 or 2 Teaspoons NOT 2 TABLESPOONS. Otherwise was good.
I am Canadian and we have Habitant soup in the can. I had a ham bone from the Holidays and found this recipe. Fantastic.....
Just finished making this recipe Used a hambone It was truly delicious !!!!! Thanks!!
This was great. I added some Cajun seasoning which provided a lovely afterburn.

I didn't even have all of the ingredients and it came out great. I used half of a can of Flakes of Ham instead of the ham bone. This is much better than Habitant is now...they now make it in the U.S. instead of Canada and it is just canned soup now.
It was delicious however I would add more peas next time.

I always loved the Habitant pea soup with ham but lately it has been expensive so I decided to try this recipe. I didn't measure anything and used all the ingredients except salt because ham is already too salty for my liking. It turned out perfect so delicious. Thankyou for sharing this recipe

Easy recipe and perfect comfort food for the cold, dreary weather of January.

I used chicken stock and omitted the salt.
I really liked it tho next time I think I'd use a little less salt but otherwise i thought it was excellent

This was great! Like others, I added chicken stock, extra bay leaves, 1/2 tsp. or so of garlic powder and oregano, and reduced the salt to 2 or 3 tsp. As a finishing touch, I added a can of coconut milk after the soup was done. Delicious...
I've been making this for years. It's my favorite split pea soup recipe.

Great starter recipe! My grandmother taught me this recipe. I dont like carrot and celery in mine also I make my broth with the ham bone then remove it before I add the peas. I use a whole small bag of peas and I add just the ham back in as the peas cook. I also add a small onion, bay leaf and thyme. I find cutting the ham off the bone easier when it's not covered in peas.
It was delicious! Didn't change a thing.
I don’t care much for pea soup, as I never liked the one in a can but this was absolutely delicious. I’d make it again.
You can also substitute chicken broth for the water.
This is the second time I've made this soup and my family really likes it. Great for warming up after a west coast rainy walk!
Made it, liked it but it was much too salty. May have been the ham used, but when I make it again, I will not add the kosher salt.
I perused several split pea soup recipes, but being a good Canadian, eh, I settled on this one. So glad I did. It was delicious. I did not make any substitutions. Definitely a keeper recipe!

French Canadian Pea Soup! Yayyyyyy! my family has made it this way for generations! Yellow split peas are the ONLY way to go! One tip...... soak the split peas overnight...they 'smush' up much faster & absorb the water you soak them in. Cover them completely. Use up any leftover pcs. of ham + a bone &/or ham hock! Delish!!!
Made this yesterday for dinner for my fiance and I. I couldn't find ham bones or turkey legs in the store where I went, so I used 2 ham steaks.

OK I hijacked the recipe. I sautéed the carrots /celery/onion in a quarter cup of butter before I added five cloves garlic. Then I added the rest of the soup ingredients and cook as instructed except I use chicken stock rather than water. I added 16 ounces of diced ham rather than a hambone. Came out fantastic although it’s far from the original recipe.
loved the simplicity of the recipe, added fresh spices such as parsley and thyme. Smells great in the house.

I'm a Canadian and use Habitant pea soup all the time for poaching and simmering frozen fish and such. I can use this recipe instead to create my own reduced-salt version of the store-bought stuff, using salt substitute (potassium chloride) as an alternative. Thanks a lot.

This is a wonderful recipe. Very easy and makes a ton. I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars because of the salt. WAY too much. Ham is salty and the addition put it over the top. The second time i made it I omitted salt completely, used celery seed instead of celery and tossed in a couple country style pork ribs. Shredded them along with the meat from the ham bone. Very hearty and tasty
Delicious! My son has said he dislikes pork, so next time I'll try smoked turkey leg.
The recipe was delicious. I only used 2 cups of yellow split peas. I didn’t use a bay leaf and I only used one teaspoon of kosher salt. It was very easy to make and oh so good.
Definitely 5 stars! This is a great recipe...so much better than from a can!

Excellent recipe! I just added ham and used chicken broth and water for the liquid. I found that I had a ready to eat soup in 45 minutes. Topped with crisp bacon, Italian parsley and onion then a pinch of smokey Spanish paprika.

Easy recipe. I added about 2 Tablespoons of maple syrup and about the same amount of Better than Broth paste.
Yummy!
Its a great recipe. Yes much better that the habitant can. Awesome comfort food for a cold day after enjoying the outdoors .Pair it with fresh bread or savory cookies.

I added a couple of potatoes and a smoked pork hock as well as a " ham steak". DELICIOUS.. You could also add a turnip or parsnip which would be good as well. Comfort Food for sure, any time of the year.

I added a couple of potatoes and a smoked pork hock as well as a " ham steak". DELICIOUS.. You could also add a turnip or parsnip which would be good as well. Comfort Food for sure, any time of the year.
Delicious!
Great soup. Kept almost all the salt (1.5 tbsp,) added a little more pepper and subbed green apples for the celery since I didn’t have any. Very much like Habitant pea soup as advertised.

Loved it. Thanks. Brought back the taste of the Netherlands that we so much miss after spending so many years living there. I looked around the kitchen and did add some bits and pieces of greens in our fridge; leek from our garden and a small slab of smoked bacon. Thanks so much! Marc

We loved it. I used a ham steak, cut in cubes, since I didn't have a ham bone. Surprisingly, the soup was ready to eat in under two hours, even though I kept the heat at a simmer and had the lid barely tilted to let a little steam out, as the recipe instructed. I left out the salt, since so many reviewers said it made it too salty. I guess my ham wasn't salty because I had to add ham to my bowl as I ate it! This is a very easy recipe and makes a big pot, so we'll be enjoying leftovers for awhile.

Absolutely delicious with a few observations:
1. Many commented on salt so I added none to start, figuring I could always add some later in the process. I don't know whether my ham was saltier than some or if it's just my personal taste - but I never ended up adding any salt and thought the result perfect.
2. I noticed pictures of the finished soup showed some large pieces of carrot that clearly hadn't started three hours earlier as diced carrot. Rather than dicing all four carrots, I sliced one and added it about 45 minutes before the soup was done.
Delicious ..first time ever making homemade pea soup and absolutely loved this recipe. Just like momma used to make!

The soup was delicious and easy to make. I replaced the Spanish onion with a yellow onion, and added some oregano, too. Lastly, I used two boxes of Swanson chicken broth instead of water. When I reheated it later, I added additional water to the soup because it became so thick. It was still wonderful! I will definitely make this again.
I am absolutely loving it, so good and so easy to make. I am (was) a big fan of the Habitant pea soups, now this is my go-to. Thanks for sharing this recipe.

I made this tonight with the exception that 8 cups of liquid was homemade chicken and veggie stock, and I added a couple cups of water as it boiled to thin it out a bit. Delicious though. Will definitely make again
I will definitely make it again but without the carrot...it changed the colour of the soup while not enhancing the flavour in any significant way.
This is delicious and my family loved it. Better than Habitant. I will put a little less salt next time because the ham is also very salty.
Great soup! I skipped the salt altogether, and didn’t have to add any when finished, but my ham was smoked and I baked the bone and meat a small amount before adding.

Absolutely delicious and a close [but better] version of Habitant canned soup. I added a couple of Poblano peppers and a heaping teaspoon of Coleman's dry mustard, but I like my food spicy; not recommended for everyone.

Easy & tasty. A little too salty, could have been a particularly salty ham bone, but next time I will add salt later rather than at the start. I am a French Canadian, this soup was exactly what I was looking for. I'll make it again.

I would have to say this is one of my favorite soups! Having spent a bit of time with people from the Acadian region of northern Maine I grew a deep appreciation for their foods. This recipe allowed me to make something special and delicious from that experience! Thank you! 
P.S. I cheated and used a ham steak and it made the soup meaty and smoky! I’d eliminate a little salt though due to the extra ham.

Yes , I added Tyme, lemon juice, marjoram, sugar, nutmeg, parsley flakes. I also added a ham bone from a ham I double smoked. I added some chicken base also.

If you never had yellow pea soup, try it. The taste has no relationship to green pea soup. Its a little closer to squash soup. I have made gallons of this stuff. I love the surprised look on peoples faces the first time they try it.
I liked it..it was very good, a little too thick, I had to keep watering it down, and yes, omit the salt..

Today will be my third time using this recipe in under 6 months. I do tweak this recipe a tiny bit every time I make it, but that's how I use recipes.

This is a really excellent recipe for a really lovely soup.

This was FANTASTIC! I wanted to make soup with our leftover Easter ham bone in my Instant Pot. I reduced the salt to 1 Tbsp and used half chicken broth & half water, pressed the Beans/Chili setting (45 mins). I've never tried yellow sweet peas before and it was a nice delicate flavor and texture - will be making this again.
Great soup! I added 4 cloves of garlic and 1 tsp smoked paprika to boost the color.
Excellent soup and this recipe is like the one my mom and grandmama use to make (both from Quebec). Added minced garlic, and a dash of cayenne because that's the way my mom and Grandmama did it.

I only gave this recipe three stars because I added and changed a lot. I used chicken broth instead of water, I also sauteed the onion with a pound of sliced mushrooms before adding to the soup. I omitted the salt and used a chicken bouillon cube. I had leftover boneless dinner ham and cubed it. I also used the celery heart and leaves, not just the stock, and also added a diced red bell pepper. I simmered for a couple hours and it turned out delicious .
Great recipe! I unfortunately overblended using my immersion blender, next time the chunks will stay... :)
first time made as directions second time used chicken broth and a little water so much tastier

This was delicious!! Whole family loved it, including two toddlers. This will be our go to recipe for pea soup. The only adjustment I would make is to double the recipe for even more soup. It didn't last long here. So good!
Update: This works beautifully in my instant pot! 45 minutes on soup/stew and it's ready. No changes to the recipe, easy peasy. Make a double batch, great leftovers! Sometimes I make it without ham if I don't have any and it's still delicious. I add in some chicken bouillon, careful with the salt, you can always add more later.
If you end up using smoked pork hocks I suggest you cut back on or completely eliminate the salt.
I added a bit of chicken stock for additional flavor . once peas were soften I blended 2 plus cups of broth mixture to make a more creamer base.

This was great. Made a few minor changes: I forgot to buy yellow peas, so used green, and I actually like the colour better. Didn't have a ham bone, but had leftover bite sized pieces (say a pound or two) in the freezer from our Christmas ham. Used maybe a 1/2 teaspoon of salt at most (plenty comes from the ham). As some others recommended, used 4 cups low sodium chicken broth, 4 cups water. After simmering 2-1/2 hours, I removed about 1/3 of the soup, blended with immersion blender, and poured back in. Simmered for another hour for good measure. Fantastic results - will make this again!
Family favorite

I would make this again. I don't usually make pea soup but this one is hearty. I guestimated the ingredients. I used a whole onion and used up the celery I had. I measured the spice in the palm of my hand and it all worked out.

I have always loved pea soup, but my husband had never liked pea soup until I tried this recipe. I followed others advice and did not add salt. I also reduced the peas so that it was not so thick. I am happily adding this to my winter soup list.

This is my go to never fail recipe for pea soup. I’m canadian and was partly raised on wonderful Habitant brand pea soup, and this is better. I cut back on the salt, but other than that stay true to recipe. It’s easy to play with if you want to modify it to suit your tastes. Very forgiving.

Very easy! Best pea soup I've ever made or tasted.
FIVE STARS!
This was way too salty, could not eat.
The best! I am a veteran soup maker and this is one of our favs!

I thought the soup was tasty , was a hit with the hubby and kids at the dinner table . ingredients are taken as a guideline not to be used as a cheap insult to some of the sour comments . anyway overall great recipe !!

I ended up with about 10 cups of water to get the consistency I wanted. I added a couple of cloves of garlic and two small potatoes diced with the ingredients. I used a ham bone with a fair amount of ham on it as the base. I also added a dash of Worcester sauce halfway through cooking. Best pea soup ever.

A good pea soup is a work of love, and this is outstanding! Bay leaves go into nearly every soup or stew I make, so don't skip this. I like more carrots. Some folks like pea soup thick, some thinner; more/less salt, or pepper? Adjust recipe seasonings to your own tastes, obviously. I've made this with a big, smoked turkey leg..awesome. Thin it with water when reheating, if you like. Left overs are great and this soup freezes well too. MAKE THIS PEA SOUP RECIPE! I was impressed.
Very good!!

Great Pea Soup and I like it better than Habitant. I am an American/Canadian living in Canada and this is as good as it gets. 
Only changes I made are: no added salt, and was out of thyme so added a few different spices. I used Chicken broth rather than water.
Very good and very simple to make. Great comfort food
Thin with chicken broth
Fabulous soup! Will cut back salt next
Ex !!!!! I made this as written with no changes Except to omit the salt ...everyone loved it ...Thank you very much for a great recipe.

Oh, I so wish I paid more attention to the reviews... When I added 2 tablespoons of salt, I said to myself.. That's a lot of salt and it sure was!! Fortunately, I was able to take out 4 cups of the soup water and then replace it with another 4 cups of regular water... I made this in the crock pot over night and woke up to yummy and delicious smells... I added a little sherry and some garlic to spice it up a little... I don't think my family would have eaten it as written.... Way too much salt...

Really Good,
Used unsalted vegetable broth 4 cups and 4 cups unsalted chicken broth with 3cups water. I like the cut up veggies also added 2cups frozen peas. If you like a thicker broth scope out half the veggies and use a blender to remaining broth.

I’ve used this recipe numerous times. I add more liquid, at least another cup or more as needed. This soup is beautiful. Near the end prior to serving, I add a tablespoon or more of vinegar to bring all the flavours together. So simple, so good.
Exceptional soup!! Made exactly as written, wouldn’t change a thing.

Turned out very well, easy soup to make, tastes amazing. I puree it once I take out the ham bone, next time I will def adjust the length of time I pure for. As with any soups, always tastes better next day.....

This was a great base. I used everything but has no ham bone. So I used vegetable stock instead and added my leftover ham. I chopped the other vegetables really small and sautéed them a bit before adding the stock and then simmered everything for 3 hours. I didn’t even have to blend it at all to make it more creamy. This is definitely a keeps. My family loves it. Thank you!!

I loved this soup! I used left over ham I had frozen and did not have any rosemary...so i used 1 tsp of dried basil, and 1 tsp of dried oregano and crossed my fingers.followed the rest exactly.. next to try with rosemary. The yellow peas were delish!

This is good soup.
i grew up on Pea Soup, so it takes a good bowl to wow me. This really good!!
Grew up thinking I hated pea soup. Apparently I only hate other pea soups, this one is fantastic. Save lots of meat on the bone to make this extra meaty.

I love a good pea soup and this recipe does hit the mark! I like to boil the ham bone the day before with onion and bay leaf
and let it cool in the fridge so I can skim off any fat.

Nila
The pot was empty before everyone was done eating! Easy and filling.
LEAVE OUT THE SALT!! Other than that this dish is excellent tasty-as comfort food - warm happy bellies happen whenever i make it :)
We followed the directions to a T and it turned out great.

I make this all the time, but use a Smoked Pork Hock in place of the ham bone. I also change the thyme for savory. You are fortunate not to get Habitat Pea Soup, its loaded with salt. I know because I'm a Canadian, and that is one of my Husbands favourites. However I tend to eat a fair bit of the pork hock before it makes it to the soup.
Half the salt and still a bit too salty tasting - otherwise simple and very good!!

This soup is AMAZING and so easy it's silly. I used all the ingredients except the bay leaf and thyme (only because I didn't have any) and salt which I added later to taste. I cooked it covered in the crock pot (because I'm lazy) all day on low though I did turn it up to high for an hour in the middle of the day to push it along. I had to add some extra ham at the in the last hour because there was not much on the bone. I didn't add salt till the end only because my dad once made split pea soup with too much salt and I didn't want to face that problem. I set the lid ajar near the end until it hit the consistency I was looking for. So simple, so good, my house smelled heavenly all day long. A real keeper!

This was without a doubt the best pea soup we have ever had. My husband and I grew up in Québec where pea soup was a staple every Friday. I did cut back on the salt, I only used 3/4 tbs and a full onion. It turned out nice and creamy and extremely tasty. I highly recommend it.

I think the amount of salt indicated must be wrong. I made this with only half the salt listed and it is still way too salty. The soup is very good but the salt is just too much. I would suggest to others to only add 1/2 to 1 tsp and then add more to taste if necessary.
Made it as directed except I sauteed onion,carrots and celery with a little garlic first. Excellent.
I have been looking for a pea soup I would enjoy for years ... I found it.
Great recipe, will definitely make it again. Comfort food on a cold winter's day.
